metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Analyse the use of gravitational fields to accelerate mass, including: gravitational field and gravitational force concepts: g = GM/r² and Fg = Gm₁m₂/r²; potential energy changes in a uniform gravitational field: Eg = mgΔh

gravitational_field_formula.name: Gravitational Field Strength Formula
gravitational_field_formula.correct: Gravitational field strength g = GM/r², where G is the gravitational constant, M is the source mass, and r is the distance from the centre of mass.

g = Gm/r².error: Wrong mass. Use the source mass M, not the test mass m.
g = Gm/r².fix: The field is created by the SOURCE. g = GM/r² uses the mass creating the field.
g = Gm/r².action: Earth's field doesn't depend on YOUR mass. It depends on Earth's mass.

g = GM/r.fix: It's an inverse SQUARE law. r must be squared in the denominator.
g = GM/r.action: Check the formula: g = GM/r². The r² is essential.

g = GMr².error: r² should be in the denominator, not multiplied.
g = GMr².fix: Field strength DECREASES with distance, so r² divides.
g = GMr².action: Think about it: is gravity stronger or weaker far from Earth?

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the correct formula structure.
persistent.action: Write g = GM/r² ten times. Then calculate g at two different distances from Earth.

gravitational_field_source.name: Field Source Mass
gravitational_field_source.correct: The gravitational field strength depends ONLY on the mass of the object creating the field, not on any test mass placed in it.

both masses.error: Field strength is independent of test mass.
both masses.fix: g = GM/r² has no 'm' for test mass. Only M matters.
both masses.action: Compare: a feather and a hammer experience the same g near Earth.

the smaller mass.error: Size doesn't determine which mass creates the field.
the smaller mass.fix: The source mass M is the one creating the field being measured.
the smaller mass.action: When near Earth, Earth is M regardless of object size.

the test mass.error: The test mass experiences the field, it doesn't create it.
the test mass.fix: M is the source mass creating the field. Test mass just responds to it.
the test mass.action: Think: Earth creates the field. Objects fall IN that field.

persistent.gap: You're confusing source mass and test mass in field calculations.
persistent.action: Key distinction: M creates the field, m experiences it. g = GM/r² uses only M.

inverse_square_law.name: Inverse Square Law
inverse_square_law.correct: Gravitational field strength decreases with the SQUARE of distance. Double the distance means one quarter the field strength.

inversely proportional to r.error: It's inverse SQUARE, not just inverse.
inversely proportional to r.fix: g ∝ 1/r² means doubling r gives 1/4 the field, not 1/2.
inversely proportional to r.action: Calculate: if r doubles, g becomes g/(2²) = g/4.

directly proportional to r².error: Opposite relationship. Field DECREASES with distance.
directly proportional to r².fix: Further from source = weaker field. It's an inverse relationship.
directly proportional to r².action: Is gravity stronger or weaker on a mountaintop vs sea level?

independent of r.fix: Only uniform fields (near Earth's surface) are approximately constant.
independent of r.action: Compare g at Earth's surface vs at twice the radius.

persistent.gap: You don't understand inverse square relationships.
persistent.action: Calculate field at r, 2r, 3r. Verify the pattern: 1, 1/4, 1/9.

gravitational_constant.name: Universal Gravitational Constant
gravitational_constant.correct: G is the universal gravitational constant: 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ N m² kg⁻². It is the same everywhere in the universe.

9.8 m s⁻².error: That's g (field strength at Earth's surface), not G.
9.8 m s⁻².fix: G is universal constant. g varies by location.
9.8 m s⁻².action: G ≈ 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹. g ≈ 9.8 on Earth. Different things.

6.67 × 10⁻⁸ N m² kg⁻².error: Wrong exponent. Off by 3 orders of magnitude.

varies by planet.error: G is a universal constant, same everywhere.
varies by planet.fix: g varies by planet. G is always the same.
varies by planet.action: G is like π—a fixed number. g depends on M and r.

persistent.gap: You're confusing G and g, or not memorising the constant.
persistent.action: Make a flashcard: G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ (universal), g = GM/r² (varies).

gravitational_force_formula.name: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation
gravitational_force_formula.correct: The gravitational force between two masses is Fg = Gm₁m₂/r². Both masses contribute to the force.

Fg = Gm₁m₂/r.fix: Gravitational force follows inverse square law. It's r², not r.
Fg = Gm₁m₂/r.action: Check: Fg = Gm₁m₂/r². The r² is essential.

Fg = Gm₁m₂r².fix: Force DECREASES with distance, so r² is in the denominator.
Fg = Gm₁m₂r².action: Think: do you weigh more or less far from Earth?

Fg = GM/r².error: That's field strength g, not force F.
Fg = GM/r².fix: Force needs both masses: Fg = Gm₁m₂/r². Field uses only source mass.
Fg = GM/r².action: Force = field × mass, so Fg = mg = m(GM/r²) = Gm₁m₂/r².

persistent.gap: You're confusing force and field formulas.
persistent.action: Remember: g = GM/r² (field), Fg = Gm₁m₂/r² (force). Force needs both masses.

action_reaction_gravity.name: Action-Reaction in Gravity
action_reaction_gravity.correct: The gravitational force between two objects forms an action-reaction pair. Earth pulls on you with the same force you pull on Earth.

the larger mass exerts more force.error: Both objects exert EQUAL forces on each other.
the larger mass exerts more force.fix: Newton's third law: action equals reaction. Forces are equal.
the larger mass exerts more force.action: Fg = Gm₁m₂/r² is symmetric. Same force on both masses.

only the larger mass exerts force.error: Both masses exert gravitational force on each other.
only the larger mass exerts force.fix: Every mass attracts every other mass. Both exert force.
only the larger mass exerts force.action: You pull on Earth just as Earth pulls on you. Same magnitude.

forces depend on which mass is larger.error: Force magnitude is the same regardless of which is larger.
forces depend on which mass is larger.fix: Fg = Gm₁m₂/r² gives ONE value—the force on both objects.
forces depend on which mass is larger.action: Different accelerations (a = F/m), but same forces.

persistent.gap: You're not applying Newton's third law to gravity.
persistent.action: Key insight: equal forces, different accelerations. a = F/m differs because m differs.

uniform_field_gpe.name: GPE in Uniform Fields
uniform_field_gpe.correct: In a uniform gravitational field (near Earth's surface), gravitational potential energy change is Eg = mgΔh.

Eg = mgh².error: Height is not squared in the GPE formula.
Eg = mgh².fix: Eg = mgΔh. Linear relationship with height.
Eg = mgh².action: Check units: kg × m/s² × m = Joules. No need for h².

Eg = ½mgh.error: No factor of ½ in gravitational PE.
Eg = ½mgh.fix: That ½ is for kinetic energy. GPE is just mgΔh.
Eg = ½mgh.action: Don't confuse with KE = ½mv². GPE = mgΔh has no ½.

Eg = mg/h.fix: More height = more PE. h should multiply, not divide.
Eg = mg/h.action: Think: lifting something higher stores MORE energy.

persistent.gap: You're confusing GPE with other energy formulas.
persistent.action: Memorise separately: KE = ½mv², GPE = mgh, SPE = ½kx².

gpe_reference_point.name: GPE Reference Point
gpe_reference_point.correct: GPE is always measured relative to a reference point. Only CHANGES in height matter for energy calculations.

always measured from Earth's centre.error: Reference point can be chosen anywhere.
always measured from Earth's centre.fix: We typically choose ground level or the lowest point as zero.
always measured from Earth's centre.action: In problems, the reference is usually stated. Check it.

absolute, not relative.error: GPE is always relative to a chosen reference.
absolute, not relative.action: Set reference at bottom of problem. Measure heights from there.

depends on the object's mass.error: Reference point is independent of mass.
depends on the object's mass.fix: Mass affects PE magnitude, not where zero is defined.
depends on the object's mass.action: Reference is a choice (usually ground). Mass just scales the PE.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that GPE requires a reference point.
persistent.action: Practice: define reference points in energy problems. Only Δh matters.

field_direction.name: Gravitational Field Direction
field_direction.correct: Gravitational field lines always point TOWARD the mass creating the field. Gravity only attracts, never repels.

away from the mass.error: Reversed. Gravity pulls IN, not out.
away from the mass.fix: Field direction shows force on a test mass. Gravity pulls toward source.
away from the mass.action: Draw a mass and ask: which way would a dropped object fall?

depends on the charge.error: Gravity has nothing to do with charge.
depends on the charge.fix: Gravity depends on mass only. Electric fields depend on charge.
depends on the charge.action: Don't mix up gravitational and electric fields.

can be repulsive.fix: Unlike electric/magnetic fields, gravity never repels.
can be repulsive.action: Key difference: gravity attracts only. No negative mass exists.

persistent.gap: You're confusing gravitational field behaviour with electric fields.
persistent.action: Remember: gravity only attracts. Field points inward toward mass.

gpe_work_relationship.name: Work and GPE Relationship
gpe_work_relationship.correct: Work done BY gravity equals the DECREASE in potential energy. Objects lose PE as they fall.

work equals gain in PE.error: Work by gravity equals PE LOST, not gained.
work equals gain in PE.fix: Falling: gravity does positive work, PE decreases.
work equals gain in PE.action: Drop a ball: it speeds up (gains KE), loses PE. Energy conserved.

no work in gravitational field.error: Gravity does work whenever objects move vertically.
no work in gravitational field.fix: W = Fd. Falling objects are moved by gravitational force.
no work in gravitational field.action: Calculate: W = Fd = mgΔh. This equals the PE change.

work only when lifting.error: Gravity does work both when lifting and falling.
work only when lifting.fix: Lifting: you do positive work, gravity does negative work.
work only when lifting.action: Falling: gravity does positive work. Both are work.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the relationship between work and potential energy.
persistent.action: Key concept: ΔKE + ΔPE = 0 in freefall. PE converts to KE.

uniform_vs_nonuniform.name: Uniform vs Non-uniform Fields
uniform_vs_nonuniform.formula: Uniform: g constant; Non-uniform: g varies
uniform_vs_nonuniform.correct: Near Earth's surface, g is approximately constant (uniform field). Far from Earth, g varies with distance (non-uniform).

all gravitational fields are uniform.fix: Uniform is an approximation for small height changes near a surface.
all gravitational fields are uniform.action: g = GM/r² shows g varies with r. Only constant if r barely changes.

uniform means g = 0.error: Uniform means g is the same everywhere, not zero.
uniform means g = 0.fix: Uniform field = constant magnitude and direction.
uniform means g = 0.action: Near Earth: g ≈ 9.8 m/s² everywhere. That's uniform.

non-uniform means no gravity.error: Non-uniform means g varies, not that it's absent.
non-uniform means no gravity.fix: Far from Earth: g still exists but changes with distance.
non-uniform means no gravity.action: Satellites feel weaker g at higher altitude. Still gravity.

persistent.gap: You don't distinguish between uniform and non-uniform fields.
persistent.action: Rule: Eg = mgh works only for uniform fields. Otherwise use area under g-r graph.

acceleration_in_field.name: Acceleration Due to Gravity
acceleration_in_field.correct: In freefall, acceleration equals gravitational field strength. All objects accelerate at the same rate regardless of mass.

heavier objects accelerate faster.error: All masses accelerate equally in a gravitational field.
heavier objects accelerate faster.fix: a = F/m = mg/m = g. Mass cancels out.
heavier objects accelerate faster.action: Drop a feather and hammer in vacuum. Same acceleration.

acceleration depends on mass.error: Freefall acceleration is independent of mass.
acceleration depends on mass.fix: More mass means more force, but also more inertia. They cancel.
acceleration depends on mass.action: F = mg, a = F/m = g. The m's cancel.

acceleration is always 9.8 m/s².error: 9.8 m/s² is only for Earth's surface.
acceleration is always 9.8 m/s².fix: On Moon: g ≈ 1.6 m/s². On Mars: g ≈ 3.7 m/s².
acceleration is always 9.8 m/s².action: g = GM/r² varies by planet and altitude.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly applying F = ma to gravitational motion.
persistent.action: Work through: F = mg, so a = F/m = mg/m = g. Mass independence.

gravitational_field.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of gravitational field concepts.

sentences.text: Gravitational field strength is calculated using the formula g = {{d1}}, where M represents the {{d2}} of the object creating the field.

d1.tooltip: Which mass creates the field? How does distance affect it?

d2.tooltip: What property of an object creates a gravitational field?

sentences.text: The value G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ N m² kg⁻² is called the {{d3}} and is {{d4}} everywhere in the universe.

d3.tooltip: This constant appears in Newton's law of universal gravitation

d4.tooltip: Is G a universal constant or does it vary?

sentences.text: Gravitational field strength follows the inverse square law, meaning if the distance from a planet's centre doubles, the field strength becomes {{d5}} of the original value.

d5.tooltip: g ∝ 1/r². If r doubles, what happens to 1/r²?

gravitational_force.title: Understanding Gravitational Force
gravitational_force.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of gravitational force between masses.

sentences.text: Newton's law of universal gravitation states that the force between two masses is Fg = {{d1}}, where {{d2}} masses contribute to the force magnitude.

d1.tooltip: How many masses appear in the force formula?

d2.tooltip: Look at the formula. How many masses are multiplied?

sentences.text: According to Newton's third law, when Earth exerts a gravitational force on you, you exert a force on Earth that is {{d3}} in magnitude and {{d4}} in direction.

d3.tooltip: What does Newton's third law say about action and reaction forces?

d4.tooltip: Action and reaction forces act in which directions relative to each other?

sentences.text: Gravitational field lines always point {{d5}} the mass creating the field because gravity is always {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Which way does gravity pull a test mass?

d6.tooltip: Can gravity ever push objects apart?

potential_energy.title: Understanding Gravitational Potential Energy
potential_energy.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of gravitational potential energy.

sentences.text: In a uniform gravitational field, the change in gravitational potential energy is calculated using {{d1}}, where Δh represents the change in {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: GPE is linear with height, not squared

d2.tooltip: What changes when you lift something?

sentences.text: Gravitational potential energy is always measured relative to a {{d3}}, and only the {{d4}} in potential energy has physical meaning.

d3.tooltip: Can you choose where PE equals zero?

d4.tooltip: Is absolute PE or ΔPE more meaningful?

sentences.text: When an object falls in a gravitational field, its potential energy {{d5}} while the work done by gravity {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Does PE increase or decrease as height decreases?

d6.tooltip: When force and displacement are in the same direction, is work positive or negative?

gravitational_field.title: Applying Gravitational Field Concepts
gravitational_field.instructions: Apply your understanding of gravitational fields to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A satellite orbits Earth at twice the radius from Earth's centre compared to the surface. The field strength it experiences is {{d1}} of the surface value because g is {{d2}} to the square of distance.

d2.tooltip: As r increases, what happens to g?

sentences.text: When calculating the gravitational field of Earth, we use Earth's mass M, not the mass of objects on Earth's surface, because the field depends only on the {{d3}} creating it.

d3.tooltip: Which mass appears in g = GM/r²?

sentences.text: The value of g at Earth's surface is approximately 9.8 m s⁻², but on Mars it is only 3.7 m s⁻² because Mars has {{d4}} mass and a {{d5}} radius than Earth.

d4.tooltip: Does more mass give stronger or weaker g?

d5.tooltip: Mars is a smaller planet. How does that affect surface g?

gravitational_force.title: Applying Gravitational Force Concepts
gravitational_force.instructions: Apply your understanding of gravitational force to these scenarios.

sentences.text: When you stand on Earth, the force you exert on Earth {{d1}} the force Earth exerts on you. However, your acceleration is {{d2}} than Earth's acceleration because you have {{d3}} mass.

d1.tooltip: Newton's third law: what about action and reaction?

d2.tooltip: Same force, different masses. Use a = F/m.

d3.tooltip: Compare your mass to Earth's mass.

sentences.text: A feather and a hammer dropped in a vacuum on the Moon will hit the ground {{d4}} because gravitational acceleration is {{d5}} of the falling object's mass.

d5.tooltip: In a = F/m = mg/m, what cancels?

sentences.text: The gravitational force between two spacecraft in orbit can be calculated using Fg = Gm₁m₂/r², where r is the distance between their {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: Where is gravitational force measured from?

potential_energy.title: Applying Potential Energy Concepts
potential_energy.instructions: Apply your understanding of gravitational potential energy to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: A 2.0 kg ball is lifted 5.0 m above the ground. Using g = 9.8 m s⁻², its gain in gravitational potential energy is {{d1}} J, calculated using {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Which formula gives GPE in a uniform field?

sentences.text: The formula Eg = mgΔh is valid only in {{d3}} gravitational fields, where the value of g is approximately {{d4}} at all heights.

d3.tooltip: When can we treat g as constant?

sentences.text: When a roller coaster descends from 30 m to 10 m, its change in height is {{d5}} m and gravitational PE is converted to {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: What happens to speed as the coaster descends?

gravitational_field.title: Mastering Gravitational Field Concepts
gravitational_field.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of gravitational field concepts through synthesis and analysis.

sentences.text: At an altitude equal to Earth's radius above the surface, the distance from Earth's centre is {{d1}} times the surface radius, so g is {{d2}} of the surface value.

d1.tooltip: Surface to centre = R. Surface + R altitude = ?

sentences.text: A common misconception is that astronauts in orbit experience zero gravity. In reality, they experience {{d3}} gravity, but they are in continuous {{d4}} around Earth.

d3.tooltip: Is there gravity at ISS altitude?

d4.tooltip: What kind of motion makes astronauts feel weightless?

sentences.text: The gravitational field strength of a planet with twice Earth's mass and twice Earth's radius would be {{d5}} Earth's surface g, because the ratio M/r² would be {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: If M doubles and r doubles: (2M)/(2r)² = 2M/4r² = M/(2r²)

gravitational_force.title: Mastering Gravitational Force Concepts
gravitational_force.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of gravitational force through synthesis and problem-solving.

sentences.text: If the distance between two objects is tripled, the gravitational force becomes {{d1}} of the original because force follows {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: What law describes how F changes with r?

sentences.text: Some students believe heavier objects fall faster. This is incorrect because gravitational {{d3}} is independent of mass, even though gravitational {{d4}} depends on mass.

d3.tooltip: What quantity is the same for all falling objects?

d4.tooltip: F = mg depends on m, but a = F/m = mg/m = g doesn't.

sentences.text: The reason you don't feel the gravitational pull of nearby objects is that G is extremely {{d5}}, making the force between everyday objects {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹. Is that a big or small number?

d6.tooltip: With tiny G and small masses, what's the force magnitude?

potential_energy.title: Mastering Potential Energy Concepts
potential_energy.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of gravitational potential energy through synthesis and analysis.

sentences.text: For a spacecraft travelling far from Earth, the formula Eg = mgΔh becomes {{d1}} because the gravitational field is {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Does g stay constant far from Earth?

d2.tooltip: How does g vary with altitude in space?

sentences.text: In conservation of energy problems, if an object's kinetic energy increases by 500 J as it falls, its gravitational potential energy must {{d3}} by {{d4}} J.

d3.tooltip: Energy is conserved. If KE goes up, PE must...?

sentences.text: A ball thrown upward slows down because gravitational force does {{d5}} work on it, converting kinetic energy into {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Force is downward, motion is upward. Same or opposite?

d6.tooltip: As the ball rises, what form of energy increases?
